journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Enhanced stochastic, subharmonic, and ultraharmonic energy harvesting

contrib-group.aff: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ji-Tzuoh Lin, University of Louisville, 2210 S. Brook Street, Louisville, KY 40292, USA. Email: j0lin001@louisville.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue – 6th Annual Energy Harvesting Workshop (EHW), The Hotel Roanoke and Conference Center, Roanoke, Virginia, August 7 – 11, 2011

abstract.p: Nonlinear bistable systems have been shown to provide improved efficiency for harvesting energy from random and broadband vibration sources. This article explores the distinct frequency response in the broadened spectrum of a particular nonlinear energy harvester, a piezoelectric cantilever with magnetic coupling. The cantilever response evolves dynamically with frequency around the main cantilever resonance. Both stochastic and multifrequency vibration responses are observed and account for some of the improved efficiency. In addition, subharmonics and ultraharmonics of the main resonance, along with various combinations of these, appear. An analytical model of the bistable dynamics produces results consistent with those observed experimentally. Overall, four distinct types of efficiency improvements appear, in which the signal is amplified above the noncoupled cantilever response: (a) ultraharmonic amplification below resonance frequency, (b) stochastic amplifications in multifrequency and multiamplitude oscillations, (c) ultrasubharmonic amplification, and (d) subharmonic amplification. Taken together, the stochastic, subharmonic, and ultraharmonic responses produce an average of threefold to fivefold increase in voltage production.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In order to generate maximum power in a linear energy-harvesting system, the frequency of the vibration source must match the resonant frequency of the energy harvester (e.g. a piezoelectric cantilever). With a slight deviation from the resonance frequency, the responding amplitude decreases by many times and the output power degrades. Many naturally occurring vibration sources do not have a fixed frequency spectrum, however, and vibrate over a broad range of frequencies. In an effort to enhance the off-resonance response, nonlinearities in the cantilever motion can be introduced by the introduction of a magnetic coupling force. Stochastic motions have been long observed with a pendulum in a repulsive magnetic field (Duchesne et al., 1991; Siahmakoun et al., 1997). This has encouraged the study of nonlinear energy harvesting in recent years (Cottone et al., 2009; Erturk et al., 2009; Lin et al., 2010; Mann, 2009; Staton et al., 2009). The research includes harvesting from a Gaussian vibration source (Cottone et al., 2009) and a pink background noise (Lin and Alphenaar, 2010). In a generalization effort, the optimal relationship among the physical parameters for a coupling enhancement was provided somewhere else (Cottone et al., 2009) using Duffing oscillator. Improvements have been attributed to an advantage in the amplification of the vibration response from energy harvesters in the stochastic regime (Erturk et al., 2009; Staton et al., 2009).

This article provides an in-depth study of the response of a magnetically coupled cantilever at different frequencies. It is observed that amplification of the cantilever output occurs not only under stochastic motion but also due to subharmonic and ultraharmonic resonances in the vicinity of the main resonant frequency. The partial solutions of subharmonic and ultraharmonic are intrinsically embedded in the magnetically coupled equation as derived in forced oscillations of weakly nonlinear systems (Prosperetti, 1976). For a particular weakly coupled cantilever experimented in this article, maximum output is maintained at the resonant frequency through combination of ultraharmonic components. In a single parametrically excited scan of voltage production with nonlinear piezoelectric cantilever, four distinct types of efficiency improvements are observed, in which the signal is amplified above the linear cantilever operation: (a) ultraharmonic amplification below resonance, (b) stochastic amplifications in multifrequency and multiamplitude oscillations, (c) ultrasubharmonic amplification at multiple quarter frequencies, (d) subharmonic amplification at one-third frequencies. For the data analysis, a 1D nonlinear system coupled with piezoelectric charge production is modeled to illustrate the dynamic functions.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the setup (Lin and Alphenaar, 2010) for the magnetically coupled piezoelectric cantilever measurements. The cantilever is manufactured using commercially available unimorph piezoelectric disks consisted of a 0.09-mm-thick lead zirconate titanate (PZT) layer deposited on a 0.1-mm-thick brass shim (APC International, MFT-50T-1.9A1). The disk is cut into a 13-mm-wide by 50-mm-long strip and clamped at one end to produce a 44-mm-long cantilever. The PZT layer extends 25 mm along the length of the cantilever and the remainder is brass only. The proof mass (including the magnet and an additional fixture that holds the magnet) weighs 2.4 g, while the cantilever itself weighs 0.8 g. The electrical leads are carefully soldered with thin lead wires (134 AWP, Vishay) to the top side of the PZT and the bottom side of the shim. The piezoelectric cantilever voltage output (peak to peak) was monitored directly (open voltage) using Agilent 54624A. Vibration is generated by a shaker table (Labwork ET-126) powered by an amplified sinusoidal wave using a Yokogawa EG300 function generator and a Labwork Pa-13 amplifier. A custom LabVIEW data acquisition program measures output voltage from the cantilever beam. A 4.8-mm-diameter disk-shaped rare earth magnet (Radio Shack model 64-1895) is attached to the vibrating tip of the cantilever beam, while an opposing magnet of the same type is attached directly to the shaker table frame. In all measurements, the shaker table acceleration is set to approximately 4.2 m/s2 at its resonant frequency and the frequency swept from 0 to 50 Hz in 0.5 Hz steps. The opposing magnet fitted at the free end of the cantilever supplies a symmetrical, repulsive force about the balance of the cantilever during vibration. The horizontal separation between the magnets (designated by η) is adjusted to be approximately η = 6.5 mm. This separation provides the low compensation force for the spring force and makes the effective restoring force as small as possible near the equilibrium point.

caption.p: The experimental setup for the magnetically coupled (nonlinear) piezoelectric cantilever. The magnetic force is repulsive and bidirectional.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p: Figure 2 shows both the output of the piezoelectric cantilever as a function of shaker table vibration frequency for the linear and nonlinear cases. The voltage generated by the piezoelectric cantilever beam is directly measured by an oscilloscope treated as an open circuit. At the resonance frequency (measured to be 9.5 Hz), the output of the cantilever was 53 V, and the peak height, resonance frequency, and line width are all approximately the same for the linear and nonlinear states (here linear refers to the noncoupled state, while nonlinear refers to the magnetically coupled state). On either side of the main resonance, however, there is an additional output observed for the nonlinear cantilever, which is not observed in the linear state. As can be seen from a comparison of the linear and the nonlinear runs, the overall amplitude profile of the nonlinear run is much larger in the sense of a broadband distribution, although there are gaps between peaks in the overall pattern of the nonlinear output.

caption.p: The voltage output (peak to peak) of the piezoelectric cantilever measured as a function of frequency (dashed line for linear state and solid line for nonlinear state).

sec.p: Figure 3 shows the output of both the linear and nonlinear cantilevers measured as a function of time at selected frequency to illustrate the comparison of the linear and nonlinear dynamics. The voltage output of the nonlinear cantilever evolves with frequency, while being amplified close to the resonance frequency. The spectrum shows a variety of amplified motions and harmonics. For example, at a driving frequency as low as 6.5 Hz (between 6 and 7.5 Hz) (Figure 3(a)), both the linear and nonlinear cantilever motions follow the vibrations of the shaker table, producing periodic oscillations. However, the amplitude of the oscillations for the nonlinear cantilever is five times larger than that for the linear cantilever. At the resonant frequency (Figure 3(b)), both linear and nonlinear cantilevers oscillate at the driving frequency with equal amplitudes. At 13 Hz (Figure 3(c)), the linear cantilever motion continues to follow the vibrations of the shaker table, producing low-amplitude periodic oscillations. The nonlinear cantilever motion is aperiodic and has a magnitude that is on average three times larger than that of the linear cantilever. At 16 Hz (Figure 3(d)), the nonlinear cantilever produces a three times larger peak-to-peak amplitude than the linear cantilever and shows multiple and periodic “half-way” vibrations. At 20 Hz (Figure 3(e)), the nonlinear cantilever shows a five times larger amplitude at the frequency of 6.7 Hz than the linear output at 20 Hz. These distinct dynamics at the above-mentioned frequency will be discussed further in the data analysis section.

caption.p: The output of the linear (dashed line) and nonlinear (solid line) system in the time domain: (a) 6.5 Hz, (b) 9.5 Hz at resonance, (c) 13 Hz, (d) 16 Hz, and (e) 20 Hz.

sec.p: Note should be taken that there are two unexpected small peaks at 12.5 and 17 Hz for the linear response. The peaks at 12.5 and 17 Hz on the experiment data come from the torsion and standing wave oscillations. It is the result of how the piezoelectric cantilever was facilitated with magnet and its fixture as the proof mass. The cantilever is relatively thin and droops naturally due to the weight of proof mass a few millimeters (as shown in Figure 1) to a curve. The L-shaped fixture that holds the magnet was bolted with a screw on one side parallel to the brass shim. The magnet is then attached on the other side of the L-shaped fixture, perpendicular to the brass shim in such a way to make magnetic coupling. During the process, the cantilever was deformed and twisted slightly. As a result, the combined proof mass is slightly located off the center of the cantilever beam resulting in weight imbalance and torsion mode resonance. The fixture also creates an area where the free end is rigid with the fixture, which acts like a semifixed end, paving a way for a standing wave vibration when the cantilever is excited. Finite element analysis (FEA) simulating the structure and dimensions confirms that the first three modes of vibration include bending, torsion, and standing wave oscillations.

sec.title: Theoretical simulations
sec.p: The dynamics of the piezoelectric cantilever is modeled by a 1D driven spring–mass system coupled with the piezoelectric effect under the influence of a magnetic force Fm(z) (Erturk et al., 2009; Staton et al., 2009)

with mass m = 0.0024 kg, damping coefficient d = 0.0075 kg/s, spring constant k = 8.55 N/m, and angular frequency ω. Here, z is the vertical deflection of the cantilever, V is the generated voltage, σ = 5 × 10−6 N/V is the coupling coefficient, and A is the acceleration of the shaker table (A = 4.2 m/s2 measured at resonance frequency). The voltage output is related to the deflection of the piezoelectric cantilever through

where Rl is the equivalent resistance, Cl is the equivalent capacitance and 1/(RlCl) = 0.01, and θ = 1250 is the piezoelectric coupling coefficient in the measured circuit. The transverse magnetic force (in the z-direction) is determined from the force between two magnetic dipoles (Kraftmakher, 2007)

where M is the dipole magnetization, u0 is the permeability in air, and η is the horizontal separation between the magnets at z = 0. The correction factors a and b are included to compensate for the flexure motion of cantilever and the magnetic force along the cantilever axis (Cottone et al., 2009). The magnetization M is determined by direct measurement of the axial force between the cantilever and a fixed magnet using a reference scale (Lin et al., 2010).

The solution to the coupled differential equations (1) and (2) is determined using Maple software to give the voltage output versus time for a given driving frequency, magnetic force function, and separation η. In order to fit our experiment data, the magnetic force Fm(z) was modified by a and b parameters and used for our calculation, where M = 0.011 A m2, η = 6.5 mm, a = 1.04, and b = 1.21. As in the experiment, the output is calculated for t = 0–10 s and the maximum peak-to-peak output over the last 2 s obtained. The result of the frequency domain is showed in Figure 4, which resembles the experimental result as shown in Figure 2. Both the experiment and simulation figures show broadband vibration for the nonlinear configuration between 6 and 20 Hz.

caption.p: The simulated voltage output (peak to peak) of the piezoelectric cantilever in the frequency domain (dashed line for linear state and solid line nonlinear state).

sec.p: The simulation in Figures 5 to 9 reproduces many of the features observed in the experiment shown in Figure 3(a) to (e). The rest of Figures 5 to 9 reveals more about the complexity of the multiple harmonics in the nonlinear systems. The simulations of the time domain with the corresponding frequency selected from experiment are shown in Figures 5(a) to 9(a). Figures 5(b) to 9(b) illustrate the velocity versus voltage output of the piezoelectric cantilever in both the linear and nonlinear cases. Figures 5(c) to 9(c) are the Fourier transform of the coupled cantilever cases in Figures 5(a) to 9(a), respectively, showing the compositions of frequency components for the nonlinear states. The following section will discuss the multiple harmonic components directly derived from the nonlinear dynamic simulations.

caption.p: The theoretical analysis of excited frequency at 6.5 Hz: (a) the time domain voltage output, dashed line for linear state and solid line for nonlinear state; (b) the velocity versus voltage output, dark line for linear state and light line for nonlinear state; and (c) the Fourier transform of the nonlinear state from the data of Figure 5(a).

The theoretical analysis of excited frequency at 9.5 Hz: (a) the time domain voltage output, dashed line for linear state and solid line for nonlinear state; (b) the velocity versus voltage output, light line for linear state and dark line for nonlinear state; and (c) the Fourier transform of the nonlinear state from the data of Figure 6(a).

The theoretical analysis of excited frequency at 13 Hz: (a) the time domain voltage output, dashed line for linear state and solid line for nonlinear state; (b) the velocity versus voltage output, light line for linear state and dark line for nonlinear state; and (c) the Fourier transform of the nonlinear state from the data of Figure 7(a).

The theoretical analysis of excited frequency at 16 Hz: (a) the time domain voltage output, dashed line for linear state and solid line for nonlinear state; (b) the velocity versus voltage output, light line for linear state and dark line for nonlinear state; and (c) the Fourier transform of the nonlinear state from the data of Figure 8(a).

The theoretical analysis of excited frequency at 20 Hz: (a) the time domain voltage output, dashed line for linear state and solid line for nonlinear state; (b) the velocity versus voltage output, light line for linear state and dark line for nonlinear state; and (c) the Fourier transform of the nonlinear state from the data of Figure 9(a).

sec.title: Multiple harmonics analysis
sec.p: At a driving frequency of 6.5 Hz, as shown in Figure 5(a), both the linear and nonlinear cantilever motions follow the vibrations of the shaker table, producing periodic oscillations. The amplitude of the oscillations for the coupled cantilever, however, is approximately five times larger than that for the linear cantilever, as shown in the experiment in Figure 3(a). The velocity versus voltage in Figure 5(b) shows that the coupled cantilever has nonlinear component in voltage production. Further analysis through Fourier transformation indicates that the nonlinear cantilever shows the combination of the excited 6.5 Hz harmonic (dominant and high amplitude) and the 20 Hz ultraharmonic (three times the excited frequency), as shown in Figure 5(c).

At the resonant frequency of 9.5 Hz (Figure 6(a)), both nonlinear and linear cantilevers oscillate at the driving frequency with equal amplitude of voltage output. The responses for both the coupled and uncoupled cantilever at resonant frequency are almost identical in the voltage output. The velocity versus voltage in Figure 6(b) shows a little nonlinearity at 90° and −90° of the vibration cycles. Through Fourier transformation, as shown in Figure 6(c), the nonlinear cantilever shows some components of vibration at the excited 9.5 Hz harmonic (dominant) and the 29 Hz ultraharmonic (three times the excited frequency).

The response for the nonlinear cantilever is chaotic at 13 Hz as shown in Figure 7(a), but with average threefold larger magnitude than the linear one. The velocity versus voltage relation in Figure 7(b) shows chaotic motions for the coupled cantilever. Using Fourier transformation for Figure 7(a) results in Figure 7(c), the coupled cantilever shows the linear response of a small portion of 13 Hz component combined with a large amplitude distribution at a lower frequency that is attributed to the chaotic motion. Note that the small peaks at 12.5 and 17 Hz are not observed in the simulation as seen and discussed in the “Experimental results” section. This small torsion and standing wave bending resonance are not accounted for by the simplified 1D model used to simulate the spring–mass damping model such as an ideal cantilever.

At 16 Hz, the nonlinear cantilever is periodic (Figure 8(a)) and is three times larger (peak to peak) in magnitude than the uncoupled one, with double prone of low frequency in the upper cycle. Apparently, it is composed of different frequency and multiple harmonic motions, with large magnitude than the uncoupled motion. The evidence is also shown in the velocity versus voltage relationship in Figure 8(b), where three different cyclic loops are identifiable. Fourier transformation from time data in Figure 8(a) proves that the nonlinear cantilever delivers ultrasubharmonic vibration at n× (16/4) Hz, where n is the integer as shown in Figure 8(c).

At 20 Hz, the response for the nonlinear cantilever is periodic and also threefold larger peak-to-peak magnitude than the linear one as shown in Figure 9(a). The velocity versus voltage in Figure 9(b) shows some combination of cyclic motions for the nonlinear cantilever. According to the Fourier transformation, the coupled cantilever shows subharmonic at 6.7 Hz (dominant), three times the excited frequency, and 20 Hz (Figure 9(c)).

The mixtures of the stochastic and various harmonic features have threefold to fivefold greater voltage production than the linear standard narrowband piezoelectric cantilever. This combined features with the undamped resonant response enhance the performance well beyond that of a standard energy harvester.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the parametrically excited piezoelectric cantilever experiments, linear and nonlinear performances were compared. Overall, four distinct types of efficiency improvements appear in the nonlinear configuration, in which the signal is amplified above the linear cantilever response: low-frequency ultraharmonic amplification; stochastic amplifications in multifrequency and multiamplitude oscillations; ultrasubharmonic amplification at multiple quarter frequencies; subharmonic amplification at one-third frequencies. Taken together, the stochastic, subharmonic, and ultraharmonic responses produce an average of threefold to fivefold increase in voltage production. For energy-harvesting purposes, the mixtures of the four features together with the undamped resonant response enhance the performance well beyond that of a standard energy harvester. Furthermore, an analytical model of the bistable dynamics produces results consistent with those observed experimentally. The simulation tool could be deployed in the future investigation for nonlinear energy harvester design for broadband and beyond natural harmonic applications.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This work was funded by the Department of Energy DE-FC26-06NT42795 and the US Navy under Contract DAAB07-03-D-B010/TO-0198. Technical program oversight under the Navy contract was provided by Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division.
